bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George A. Kellogg, May 27, 1941

div1.p: Hench discusses his speech for the upcoming unveiling of the Cornwell portrait and requests more details on the event and on the painting.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George A. Kellogg, May 27, 1941
div1.opener:
May 27, 1941
Mr. George A. Kellogg
257 Cornelison Avenue
Jersey City, N. J.
My dear Mr. Kellogg:
div1.p:
I imagine your mind is so full of the details of the Cleveland affair that
you have assumed that I knew more about it than I really did. You have sent me very
meagre details and as I have wired you today, I don't have in mind the exact set-up
except that you have now told me three or four of the invited guests and that I am
to be the only speaker, which I didn't really know until yesterday. I had assumed
that somebody else would possibly discuss Wyeth's purpose in presenting the painting
to the medical profession, with some running comments on the difficulties encountered
in making it accurate. I thought perhaps you might be doing that, or Mr. Law. However,
I now assume that you will not be doing this so that I will do it, as you will see in
the enclosed partial first draft. I wish indeed I had known about this a couple of
weeks earlier. We have been dreadfully busy. Since seeing you I have attended two
more medical meetings and my associated is now attending a third, which has given
me much extra work.

I haven't had much time to freshen up the story in new language and
unless you have serious objections, I am afraid I will have to borrow generously
words and paragraphs from the Lazear dedication talk which I sent you before, but
which, for fear you can't find it, I am sending you again. (Please bring this copy
with you to Cleveland as I need it.) I am especially inclined to be allowed the priv-
ilege of repeating myself because my Lazear talk had only a very restricted publication
and of course this talk probably will not be published except in brief newspaper accounts.

Since you are giving me more or less the whole job, I am a little worried that
fifteen minutes will pass only too quickly for me, if not for the audience. The part
that I am sending you takes six minutes speaking time. I will certainly have to skip
over the story of the conquest rather briefly and can only give a couple of sentences
to the current significance of the conquest, its relation to the building of the Panama
Canal, which is now such a vital link in our defense and the relation of such American
public health activities to our friendly relations with South America. But if you think
that twenty minutes would be definitely too long, I shall slash the talk unmercifully
and make it just fifteen minutes. I should like to know whether the painting is to be
unveiled before or after the talk as the wording of the talk might be a little different
here and there. I might turn to the painting and point to the various figures, particu-
larly when I give the next to the last paragraph of the talk, but it is quite all right
and if you want to have the painting unveiled just after my talk and follow it up by
an introduction of Kissinger and Mrs. Reed, that is quite all right with me, but let
me know.

Also before I hand the talk to the newspapers I would like to know what
sibsidiary figures you finally portrayed in the painting.

I am surprised that you want fifty rather than twelve multigraphed copies
but we will do our best. I will arrive at the Hotel Cleveland Sunday morning and
would like very much to get in touch with you at your earliest convenience, as I
will be busy at an Executive Committee meeting in the afternoon. If I can possibly
airmail a few copies, to get to New York Saturday, I assume that I am to send them
to your office. OrWhere shall I send them so that if they arrive Saturday afternoon they
can still be of use to you?

I am a little concerned as to the news value of my talk. Obviously it will
have to be rewritten by the newspaper men. The head of our editorial department
thought that it would have sufficient news value as it is now outlined, but I was
hoping to hear from you if you had any special suggestions or requests for me to
put certain date in the paper.

One more final thing. There are two more friends of mine who are going to
be in Cleveland that day--Dr. and Mrs. Walter Simpson, 247 Blossom Heath Road,
Dayton, Ohio. He is a nationally known physician who has been much interested in the
Walter Reed affair and if there is still room for you to invite him I would be very
grateful if you would. If your quota is filled, could l invite him as my guest at
my own expense, as I would be only too glad to have him there.

closer.seg:
P. S. Just this minute I received your engraved invitation which looks
very nice (although my name is spelled “Philip” not “Phillip”), and your letter.
I will call you at the Allerton Hotel as soon as I arrive early Sunday morning at
the Cleveland Hotel. As the invitation looks so nice, please send one to my brother,
Dr. and Mrs. A. L. Hench, East Jefferson Street, Charlottesville, Virginia, and also
one to my mother, Mrs. J. B. Hench, 5524 Kentucky Avenue, Pittsburgh, Pa. They won't
come but I would like them to see what big company their little boy keeps!
P.S.H.
